content.description: Tricky problem that goes up the center of the face of the boulder, with a bad landing. Start standing on the back-breaker boulder under the Hard Bulge Problem, left hand side pull, pull up onto the face and slap to the big left-facing flake, top out above flake.
content.location: when standing in the creek looking at the boulder, it's right in the center, big flake yo

content.description:
This problem is thin and hard. Start on obvious right hand half-pad crimp, left hand edge on the bottom of boulder, and slap your way up and to the left, topping out on the slab above the bulge. This is a project, and it may not go; the grade is approximate, it could be 9 it could be 12, IDK. Needs some opinions, needs some traffic, needs some love. Sergio, Thanh, BA where yall at.

 Edit Jan. 2020: was informed that this problem has been done in previous years, not a project any more. was wildly wrong about the grade, both times I posted it. was a fun but sketch climb.
content.protection: 4-5 pads and spotter(s). First few moves are low to the ground, but there's a skull-splitting boulder below the spot where this problem tops out, and a tumble down from there. Maybe chossy holds at the top slab too.
content.location: East side of the Badass Boulder, there's a tree kinda close to the start

content.description: An amazing arete climb! Start low on the right side of the left-leaning arete, and ride that bad boy up through some crimps and some blocky holds, reaching the sharp point at the tip of the boulder. The boulder to the left of the arete is off, don't put your feet there. There may be a hard sit start or direct start to this climb, just waiting an ascent.
content.location: West side of the Badass Boulder, it'll be facing you when you approach from the trail. If you approach from the creek, you'll have to scramble up to it.

content.description: A truly badass free-standing boulder that stays out of the water pretty much year-round, except for maybe floods. An unknown, unnamed arete climb marks this boulder. This boulder is about the size of a full-size Mercedes Sprinter van.
